[[File:Quercus geminata 002 (homeredwardprice).jpg|thumb|Sand live oak at sunrise]]
'''''Quercus geminata''''', commonly called '''sand live oak''', is an [[evergreen]] [[oak]] [[tree]] native to the coastal regions of the subtropical [[Southeastern United States|southeastern]] [[United States]], along the [[Atlantic Ocean|Atlantic]] Coast from southern Florida northward to southeastern Virginia and along the [[Gulf Coast of the United States|Gulf Coast]] westward to southern Mississippi,<ref name=Floridata>[http://www.floridata.com/ref/q/quer_gem.cfm] "FloriData — Quercus geminata", Retrieved 2011-07-06</ref> on seacoast dunes and on white sands in evergreen oak scrubs.<ref name=Trees_North_FL/>

A small- to medium-sized tree, the sand live oak is scrubby and forms thickets. The bark is dark, thick, furrowed, and roughly ridged. The leaves are thick, leathery, and coarsely veined, with extremely revolute margins, giving them the appearance of inverted shallow bowls; their tops dark green, their bottoms dull gray and very tightly [[tomentose]], and their [[Petiole (botany)|petiole]]s densely pubescent, they are simple and typically flat with bony-opaque margins, having a length of 0.75–4.5 inches (2–12 cm) and a width of 0.2–1.5 inches (0.5–4 cm).  The male flowers are green hanging [[catkin]]s.  The acorns are small, 0.5–1 inch (1–2.5 cm), oblong-ellipsoid or ovoid, and are commonly born in pairs on [[Peduncle (botany)|peduncle]]s of varying lengths.<ref name=Trees_North_FL/><ref name=Trees_Florida/>

In coastal [[Florida]]'s evergreen oak [[Scrubland|scrub]], the Sand Live Oak is a ubiquitous and abundant species; the threatened [[Florida scrub-jay]] is found only in [[Florida scrub]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sfrc.ufl.edu/4h/Ecosystems/Scrub/scrub.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=July 8, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110601074526/http://www.sfrc.ufl.edu/4h/Ecosystems/Scrub/scrub.html |archivedate=June 1, 2011 }} "The University of Florida – School of Forest Resources & Conservation — Scrub", Retrieved 2011-07-08</ref><ref>[http://www.brevardcounty.us/environmental_management/wildlife_scrub_jay.cfm] "AN ECOLOGICAL OVERVIEW OF SCRUB HABITAT AND FLORIDA SCRUB-JAYS IN BREVARD COUNTY", Retrieved 2011-07-08</ref>  [[Live oak]]s, having characteristics of the sand live oak and the [[Quercus virginiana|southern live oak]] (''Q. virginiana''), grow further inland.  It is believed that these specimens are hybrids of ''Q. geminata'' and ''Q. virginiana''.<ref name=Trees_North_FL/> While hybridization does occur between ''Q. geminata'' and ''Q. virginiana,'' the two species are genetically and morphologically distinct.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Cavender-Bares|first=Jeannine|author2=Pahlich, Anette |title=Molecular, morphological and ecological niche differentiation of sympatric sister oak species, Quercus virginiana and Q. geminata (Fagaceae)|journal=American Journal of Botany|year=2009|volume=96|pages=1690–1702|doi=10.3732/ajb.0800315|pmid=21622355}}</ref> The [[Quercus sagraeana|Cuban oak]], ''Q. sagraeana'', has been purported to be a hybrid<ref>[http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=1&taxon_id=233501037] "Flora of North America — Quercus geminata", Retrieved 2011-07-06</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Muller|first=Cornelius H.|title=The origin of ''Quercus'' on Cuba|journal=Revista de la Sociedad Cubana de Botánica|year=1955|volume=7|pages=41–47}}</ref> between the sand live oak and ''[[Quercus oleoides|Q. oleoides]]'', but recent evidence suggests that the Cuban oak is a separate species without hybrid origin.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Gugger|first=Paul F.|author2=Cavender-Bares, Jeannine |title=Molecular and morphological support for a Florida origin of the Cuban oak|journal=Journal of Biogeography|year=2012|doi=10.1111/j.1365-2699.2011.02610.x|volume=40|pages=632–645}}</ref>

'''''Quercus georgiana''''', the '''Georgia oak''' or '''Stone Mountain oak''', is a rare deciduous red [[oak]], native to the southeastern United States.

== Distribution ==
The Georgia oak is native to the southeastern United States, mainly in northern [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], but with additional populations in [[Alabama]], [[North Carolina]], and [[South Carolina]].<ref>[http://bonap.net/MapGallery/County/Quercus%20georgiana.png Biota of North America Program 2014 county distribution map]</ref> It grows on dry granite and sandstone outcrops of slopes of hills at {{convert|50|–|500|m|ft|sp=us}} altitude.<ref>{{IUCN2006|assessor=Nixon, K. |display-assessors=etal|year=1998|id=34011|title=Quercus georgiana|downloaded=11 May 2006}} Listed as Endangered (EN B1+2ce v2.3)</ref><ref name="samantha" />

The tree was first discovered in 1849 at [[Stone Mountain]], Georgia, where several stands of pure specimens grow along the popular walk-up trail at around 1,300 feet (near the large chestnut oak in the middle of the trail and before the rest pavilion halfway up the trail).<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.internationaloaksociety.org/content/quercus-georgiana-ma-curtis|title=Quercus georgiana M.A. Curtis|date=2014-11-18|work=International Oak Society|access-date=2017-05-04}}</ref> Georgia oaks are also found at nearby [[Inselberg|monadnocks]], including [[Panola Mountain]] and [[Arabia Mountain]] in Georgia.

== Description ==
''Quercus georgiana'' is a small [[tree]], often [[shrub]]by in the wild, growing to {{convert|8|–|15|m|ft|sp=us}} tall. It is classified in the red oak section [[List of Quercus species#Section Lobatae|''Quercus'' sect. ''Lobatae'']].

=== Leaves ===
[[File:Quercus georgiana leaves in late spring 05.jpg|alt=Quercus georgiana leaves|thumb|Quercus georgiana leaves]]
[[File:Quercus georgiana winter leaves in early spring.jpg|alt=Brown winter leaves on Georgia oak|thumb|Brown winter leaves on Georgia oak]]
The shiny green leaves are {{convert|4|–|13|cm|in|round=0.5|abbr=on}} long and {{convert|2|–|9|cm|in|round=0.5|abbr=on}} wide, with a {{convert|0.6|-|2.3|cm|in|round=0.5|abbr=on}} petiole, and five irregular, pointed, bristle-tipped lobes; they are glabrous (hairless), except for small but conspicuous tufts of hairs in the vein axils on the underside. The leaves turn dark red to brown in the autumn, stay on the tree throughout the winter, and fall as the new leaves bud in the spring.

=== Flowering and fruiting ===
Like all oaks, flowering and leaf-out occur in late spring when all frost danger has passed. The flowers are monoecious catkins which, being self-incompatible, require the presence of another oak for pollination.
[[File:Quercus georgiana catkins in early spring 01.jpg|alt=Catkins on a Georgia oak|thumb|Catkins on a Georgia oak]]

The acorns are round, 9–14 mm long, maturing about 18 months after pollination.<ref name="samantha">[http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=1&taxon_id=233501038 Flora of North America - ''Quercus georgiana'']</ref>

=== Twigs and buds ===
Twigs are deep red, 1–2 mm in diameter and glabrous. Terminal buds are red-brown, ovoid to subconic, 2.5–5 mm, and glabrous or with scales somewhat ciliate.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=1&taxon_id=233501038|title=Quercus georgiana in Flora of North America @ efloras.org|website=www.efloras.org|access-date=2017-05-04}}</ref>

=== Bark ===
Bark is gray to light brown, scaly.  
[[File:Quercus georgiana twig and buds in early spring 01.jpg|alt=Georgia oak twig and buds|thumb|Georgia oak twig and buds]]

== Uses ==
It is occasionally cultivated as a specimen or garden tree in [[USDA plant hardiness zone]]s 5-8. Besides landscape [[horticulture]], the Georgia oak has no commercial uses.

'''''Quercus laevis''''', the '''turkey oak''', is a member of the [[red oaks|red oak]] group of [[oak]]s. It is native to the southeastern United States, occurring on the coastal plain from [[Virginia]] south to [[central Florida]], and west to southeast [[Louisiana]].<ref>[http://bonap.net/MapGallery/County/Quercus%20laevis.png Biota of North America Program 2014 county distribution map]</ref> The name turkey oak derives from the resemblance of the leaves to a turkey's foot.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sfrc.ufl.edu/4h/Turkey_oak/turkeoak.htm |title=Turkey oak (''Quercus laevis'') |work=Florida Forest Trees |publisher=[[University of Florida]] |accessdate=February 8, 2010}}</ref> A [[Turkey|Turkish]] and southern [[Europe]]an species ''[[Quercus cerris]]'' is also commonly referred to as Turkey oak, so ''Quercus laevis'' is sometimes referred to as '''American turkey oak''' to distinguish it from the European species.

[[Image:AmericanTurkeyOakTree.jpg|left|thumb|Turkey oak trees]]
''Quercus laevis'' is a small [[tree]], sometimes [[shrub]]by, typically only {{convert|8|-|10|m}} tall, though occasionally reaching {{convert|18|m}}. The leaves are variable in size, mostly {{convert|10|-|17|cm}} long but occasionally just {{convert|8|cm}} or as much as {{convert|30|cm}} long. They have 3–7 slender lobes, deeply incised between the lobes, each lobe with 1–3 bristle teeth at the tip. The acorns are about {{convert|20|-|25|mm}} long, and, like other red oaks, take 18 months to mature.<ref>[http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=1&taxon_id=233501054 Flora of North America, ''Quercus laevis'' Walter, 1788.  Turkey oak ]</ref>

[[Image:Quercus laevis-1.jpg|thumb|left|A stand of turkey oaks growing on white sand near the banks of the [[Ocmulgee River]] in the state of Georgia]]
Turkey oak typically grows on poor, thin, dry, rocky or sandy soils where few other oaks other than Blackjack oak, ''[[Quercus marilandica|Q. marilandica]]'', can thrive. It does not have the beautiful crown form of many oaks, but is nonetheless a valuable tree for growing on infertile, dry, sandy sites. The deeply lobed leaves are also attractive. It associates as an understory tree with [[Pinus palustris|longleaf pine]] and other [[pine]] stands on sandy knolls in the southeastern United States.

'''''Quercus laurifolia''''' ('''swamp laurel oak''', '''diamond-leaf oak''', '''water oak''', '''obtusa oak''', '''laurel oak''') is a medium-sized semi-evergreen [[oak]] in the [[List of Quercus species|red oak]] section ''Quercus'' sect. ''Lobatae''. It is native to the southeastern and south-central the [[United States]], from coastal [[Virginia]] to central [[Florida]] and west to southeast [[Texas]].<ref>[http://www.plantmaps.com/nrm/quercus-laurifolia-laurel-oak-native-range-map.php Interactive Distribution Map of ''Quercus laurifolia'']</ref> There are reports of the species growing in [[Pennsylvania]] and [[New Jersey]], but these probably represent introductions.<ref>[http://bonap.net/MapGallery/County/Quercus%20laurifolia.png Biota of North America Program 2014 county distribution map]</ref>

''Quercus laurifolia'' is a [[tree]] growing to {{convert|65|–|80|ft|m|abbr=off|sp=us}} (rarely to {{convert|130|ft|m|abbr=off|sp=us}}) tall, with a large, circular crown. The [[leaf|leaves]] are broad lanceolate, {{convert|1|-|5|in|cm|abbr=off}} long and {{convert|0.5|-|1.75|in|cm|abbr=off}} broad, and unlobed (very rarely three-lobed) with an entire margin and a bristle tip; they typically fall just as the new leaves start to emerge in spring. The [[acorn]]s, borne in a shallow cup, are hemispherical, {{convert|0.35|-|0.5|in|mm|abbr=off}} long, green, maturing blackish-brown about 18 months after pollination. Despite their bitter kernel, they are eaten by deer, squirrels and birds. Acorn production is often heavy, enhancing the species' value for wildlife.<ref name=jacqui/>

The seedlings show embryo [[dormancy]] and [[germinate]] the following spring after fall ripening; germination is [[hypogeal germination|hypogeal]].

Swamp laurel oak grows rapidly and usually matures in about 50 years which has led to its wide use as an ornamental. It is host to the general oak-feeding insects but has no serious insect problems. Several species of ''[[Curculio]]'' weevils infest the acorns.

The botanist C.J. Burke<ref>Burke, C. J. (1961). An evaluation of three hybrid-containing oak populations on the North Carolina Outer Banks. Journal of the Elisha Mitchell Scientific Society 78(l):18-21.</ref><ref>Burke, C. J. (1963). The hybrid nature of Quercus laurifolia. Journal of the Elisha Mitchell Scientific Society 79(2):159-163.</ref> suggested that swamp laurel oak is of [[Hybrid (biology)|hybrid]] origin having been derived from [[Willow oak|willow oak ''(Quercus phellos)'']] and [[Water oak|water oak ''(Quercus nigra)'']]; it is not found outside the ranges of the two supposed parental species. This conclusion was based on an index from leaf-shape on seedlings grown from acorns. However, this theory has not achieved wide support, with current authors accepting ''Quercus laurifolia'' as a distinct species ''(e.g. [[Flora of North America]]).''<ref name=jacqui>[http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=1&taxon_id=233501055 Flora of North America: ''Quercus laurifolia'' Swamp Laurel Oak]</ref>

Known hybrids with ''Quercus laurifolia'' as one parent are with ''Q. falcata'' (''Q × beaumontiana'' Sarg.), ''Q. incana'' (''Q. × atlantica'' Ashe), and ''Q. marilandica'' (''Q. × diversiloba'' Tharp ex A. Camus).

==Soils and climate==
Swamp laurel oak is found mostly on [[alluvial]] [[flood plain]]s, from sea level up to {{convert|150|m|ft|abbr=off|sp=us}} altitude. It will tolerate the wetter sites in association with other oak species but will not live with continuous or prolonged [[flood]]ing. It is most often found growing in sandy soil near [[river]]s and along the edges of [[swamp]]s if not too frequently flooded. Swamp laurel oak grows in the [[hammock (ecology)|hammocks]] of central Florida and on sand hills adjacent to swamps in west Florida. Swamp laurel oak grows best on [[ultisol]]s and [[inceptisol]]s.

The range has average annual temperatures from {{convert|16|to|21|C|F}}. It can withstand extreme lows ranging from {{convert|-1|to|-18|C|F}}. Extreme highs range from {{convert|38|to|43|C|F}}.

It needs between {{convert|1250|-|1500|mm|in|abbr=on}} of rainfall a year. From {{convert|500|-|1000|mm|in|abbr=on}} of this is received during the growing season from April to September.

==Uses==
It is grown and marketed mainly as [[pulpwood]]. It is commonly used as an [[ornamental tree]] in landscaping because of its fast growth and pleasing appearance; it is planted with little regard to soil type. The acorns provide food for [[raccoon]]s, [[white-tailed deer]], [[wild turkey]]s, [[squirrel]]s, [[duck]]s, [[bobwhite quail]], and small [[bird]]s and [[rodent]]s.

'''''Quercus lyrata''''' ('''overcup oak''') is an [[oak]] in the [[List of Quercus species#Section Quercus|white oak]] group (''Quercus'' sect. ''Quercus''). It is native to lowland wetlands in the eastern and south-central United States, in all the coastal states from [[New Jersey]] to [[Texas]], inland as far as [[Oklahoma]], [[Missouri]], and [[Illinois]]. There are historical reports of it growing in [[Iowa]], but the species appears to have been extirpated there.<ref>[http://bonap.net/MapGallery/County/Quercus%20lyrata.png Biota of North America Program 2014 county distribution map]</ref>

==Description==
[[Image:Quercus lyrata (USDA).jpg|left|thumb|Overcup oak acorns, showing the nut largely enclosed by the acorn cup]]
Quercus lyrata is a medium-sized [[deciduous]] [[tree]], growing to {{convert|20|m|ft|abbr=off|sp=us}}  tall, with a trunk up to {{convert|80|cm|in|round=0.5|abbr=on}} (rarely {{convert|140|cm|in|round=0.5|abbr=on}}) diameter.

The [[leaf|leaves]] are {{convert|10|–|16|cm|in|round=0.5|abbr=on}} (rarely {{convert|20|cm|in|round=0.5|abbr=on}}) long and {{convert|5|–|10|cm|in|round=0.5|abbr=on}} broad, deeply lobed, often somewhat [[lyre]]-shaped (lyrate), dark green above, paler and often finely hairy beneath.

The [[flower]]s are [[catkin]]s, produced in the spring and maturing in about 6–7 months into [[acorn]]s {{convert|2.5|–|5|cm|in|abbr=on}} long and {{convert|2|–|4|cm|in|round=0.5|abbr=on}} broad, largely enclosed by the [[Calybium and cupule|cupule]] (acorn cup).<ref>[http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=1&taxon_id=233501057 Flora of North America: ''Quercus lyrata'']</ref>

The common name comes from the acorns being largely enclosed in the cup; the scientific name comes from the [[Leaf shape|lyrate]] ([[lyre]]-shaped) leaves.

The [[wood]] is valuable, similar to that of other white oaks, and used for the same purposes.

'''''Quercus marilandica''''' ('''blackjack oak''') is a small [[oak]], one of the [[list of Quercus species#Section Lobatae|red oak group]] ''Quercus'' sect. ''Lobatae''. It is native to the eastern and central United States, from [[Long Island]] to [[Florida]], west as far as [[Texas]], [[Oklahoma]], and [[Nebraska]]. There are reports of a few isolated populations in southern [[Michigan]], but these appear to represent introductions.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://esp.cr.usgs.gov/data/atlas/little/quermari.pdf | title = Quercus marilandica Range Map | accessdate = 2008-03-05 | publisher = [[United States Geological Survey]]}}</ref><ref>[http://bonap.net/MapGallery/County/Quercus%20marilandica.png Biota of North America Program 2014 county distribution map]</ref>

[[Image:Lewis County Blackjack Oak.JPG|left|thumb|Blackjack oak leaves]]
[[Image:Oak-Stump-9832.jpg|left|thumb|Blackjack oak stump, approx. 75 years old]]
''Quercus marilandica'' is a small [[deciduous]] [[tree]] growing to {{convert|15|m|ft|abbr=off|sp=us}} tall, with bark cracked into rectangular black plates with narrow orange fissures. The [[leaf|leaves]] are {{convert|7|-|20|cm|in|round=0.5|abbr=on}} long and broad, and typically flare from a tapered base to a broad three-lobed bell shape with only shallow indentations. They are dark green and glossy above, pubescent underneath, and often remain attached to the twigs through the winter after turning colors from red to brown in the fall. The [[acorn]] is small, {{convert|12|-|20|mm|in|abbr=on}} long and {{convert|10|-|18|mm|in|abbr=on}} broad; like other red oaks, it takes 18 months to mature.<ref>[http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=1&taxon_id=233501060 Flora of North America, ''Quercus marilandica'' Münchhausen, 1770. Blackjack oak ]</ref>

==Habitat and distribution==

The blackjack oak grows in poor, thin, dry, rocky or sandy soils where few other woody plants can thrive, usually on low ground, from sea level up to approximately {{convert|2800|ft|m|abbr=off|sp=us}} in altitude. Some say that it does not have the beautiful form of many oaks, but is nonetheless a valuable tree for growing in problem sites.<ref>[http://www.ingentaconnect.com/content/saf/jof/1942/00000040/00000003/art00011?crawler=true]</ref> Some say that the tree is "tough but ugly," but also underappreciated.<ref>[http://www.uaex.edu/yard-garden/resource-library/plant-week/blackjack-oak.aspx]</ref><ref>[http://www.tallahassee.com/story/life/home-garden/2017/01/12/blackjack-oak-grows-hardscrabble-habitat/96497394/]</ref> At times the tree has even been actively eradicated to provide more room for trees deemed to be more commercially valuable.<ref>[https://archive.org/stream/sproutingofblack137clar/sproutingofblack137clar_djvu.txt]</ref>

It is sometimes an understory tree in pine stands on sandy knolls in the southeastern USA. Along the coastal plain of [[New Jersey]] the probability of finding this species is increased in relatively sunny, open areas such as those near coastal salt marshes. It often occurs near [[Scarlet Oak|scarlet]] and [[post oak]]s as well as [[pitch pine]]; understory companions include [[winged sumac]], [[bracken]], [[sweetfern]], and [[bayberry]], and can be found as far north as parts of Ohio,<ref>[http://www.oplin.org/tree/fact%20pages/oak_blackjack/oak_blackjack.html]</ref> New York,

A variety, ''Quercus marilandica'' Münchhausen var. ''ashei'' [[George Bishop Sudworth|Sudworth]] (D. M. Hunt 1989), grows in the western portions of its range—northern [[Texas]], [[Oklahoma]], and into southern [[Kansas]]. In this area, blackjack, along with [[post oak]], forms a semi-savanna area composed of forested strips intermixed with prairie grass glades along the eastern edge of the southern [[Great Plains]]. This semi-savanna is known as the [[Cross Timbers]].<ref>[http://www.biosurvey.ou.edu/posters/CrossTimbersEcoregion.html]</ref><ref>[http://www.forestry.ok.gov/post-oak-blackjack-forest]</ref><ref>[http://texnat.tamu.edu/library/symposia/brush-sculptors-innovations-for-tailoring-brushy-rangelands-to-enhance-wildlife-habitat-and-recreational-value/oak-ecology/]</ref> Scrub forms of ''Q. marilandica'' dominate on many [[chert]] glades along with ''[[Quercus stellata|Q.stellata]]'' in Arkansas' Ozark plateau.<ref>C.Michael Hogan. 2012. [http://www.eoearth.org/article/Oak ''Oak''. Encyclopedia of Earth. Eds. A. Dawson and C.J. Cleveland. Encyclopedia of Earth. National Council for Science and the Environment. Washington DC] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130523173442/http://www.eoearth.org/article/Oak |date=May 23, 2013 }}</ref>

The Blackjack Oak sometimes hybridizes with the Bear Oak ([[Quercus ilicifolia]]), forming a hybrid known as [[Q. X brittonii]].<ref>[http://eol.org/pages/1151451/details]</ref>

Blackjacks in the Cross Timbers can grow from {{convert|50|to|60|ft|m}} high with a trunk diameter of {{convert|16|in|cm}}, but seldom reach more than {{convert|40|ft|m}}. The leaves are from {{convert|4|to|10|in|cm}} in length and about the same width. Blackjack acorns provide food for both whitetail deer and wild turkey. Blackjacks may, however, cause [[tannic acid]] poisoning in cattle.

==Uses==
The [[wood]] is very dense and produces a hot flame when burned, which functions as an excellent source of heat for [[barbecue]]s and wood-burning stoves. However, the wood is not desirable for wood [[fireplace]]s because the heat causes popping, thereby increasing the risk of house fires.<ref>Stephan L. Hatch and Jennifer Pluhar (eds.). Texas Range Plants. College Station: Texas A&M University Press, 1999. ISBN 0-89096-538-2</ref>

Traditionally blackjack wood is used as both a fuel and smoke wood for [[barbecue in Oklahoma]].

'''''Quercus michauxii''''', the '''swamp chestnut oak''', is a species of [[oak]] in the [[List of Quercus species#Section Quercus|white oak section]] ''Quercus'' section ''Quercus'' in the beech family. It is native to bottomlands and wetlands in the eastern and central [[United States]], in coastal states from [[New Jersey]] to [[Texas]], inland primarily in the [[Mississippi Valley|Mississippi]]/[[Ohio Valley]] as far as [[Oklahoma]], [[Missouri]], [[Illinois]], and [[Indiana]].<ref>[http://bonap.net/MapGallery/County/Quercus%20michauxii.png Biota of North America Program 2014 county distribution map]</ref>

==Classification and nomenclature==
The swamp chestnut oak closely resembles the [[chestnut oak]] ''Quercus prinus'', and for that reason has sometimes been treated as a variety of that species.  However, the swamp chestnut oak is a larger tree which differs in preferred habitat, and the [[bark]] does not have the distinctive deep, rugged ridging of the chestnut oak, being thinner, scaly, and paler gray. It typically grows to around 65 feet (20 meters) tall, though the tallest specimen currently known is over 150 feet (42 meters) tall.

The name ''Q. prinus'' was long used by many botanists and foresters for the swamp chestnut oak, even when treated as a species distinct from the chestnut oak, which was then called ''Q. montana'', but the application of the name ''Q. prinus'' to the chestnut oak is now often accepted,<ref>The confusion arose from differing identifications of the [[type (biology)|type specimens]] for the [[Linnaeus|Linnaean]] name, by some (but not all) botanists considered resolved by close examination of the leaf pubescence, which differs in the two species.</ref> although sometimes that name is declared to be of uncertain position, unassignable to either species, with the chestnut oak then called ''[[Quercus montana|Q. montana]]'', as in the ''Flora of North America''<ref name="FNA Qmontana">[http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=1&taxon_id=233501064 Flora of North America, ''Quercus montana'' Willdenow, 1805.  Mountain chestnut oak, rock chestnut oak ]</ref>

==Description==
The [[leaf|leaves]] of the swamp chestnut oak are simple (not compound), 4-11 in (10–28 cm) long and 2-7 in (5–18 cm) broad, with 15-20 lobe-like, rounded simple teeth on each side, similar to those of chestnut oak and [[Quercus muehlenbergii|chinkapin oak]] (''Quercus muehlenbergii''), although they generally do not achieve the more slender form that the leaves of those trees may exhibit at times. The [[fruit]] is an [[acorn]] 1-1½ in (2.5-3.5 cm) long and ¾-1 in (2-2.5) cm broad, borne on a ¾-1¼ nin (2–3 cm) peduncle, maturing in the fall, about 6 months after pollination.<ref>[http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=1&taxon_id=233501061 Flora of North America, ''Quercus michauxii'' Nuttall, 1818. Basket oak, cow oak, swamp chestnut oak ]</ref>

==Uses==
The [[wood]] of the swamp chestnut oak is similar to, and usually marketed mixed with, that of other white oaks.{{citation needed|date=October 2011}} Swamp chestnut oak is also called basket oak, since the wood is easily split into long, thin, flexible strips excellent for basket weaving.<ref>Missouri Department of Conservation, Field Guide, Swamp Chestnut Oak</ref>
The swamp chestnut oak's [[acorn]]s are large and relatively sweet.<ref name="Kirkman, Brown, Leopold 2007 182–183">{{cite book|last=Kirkman, Brown, Leopold|title=Native Trees of the Southeast|year=2007|publisher=Timber Press|location=Portland, Oregon|pages=182–183}}</ref>   They are readily eaten by [[livestock]],{{citation needed|date=October 2011}}<ref name="Kirkman, Brown, Leopold 2007 182–183"/>  and the species is sometimes called the "cow oak" for this reason.  However, swamp chestnut oaks bear heavy crops of acorns only at intervals of several years.<ref name="Kirkman, Brown, Leopold 2007 182–183"/> Acorns in general are potentially fatal if eaten by horses.

The swamp chestnut oak is sometimes cultivated as a large garden tree or street tree, and is quite easy to grow if it is not subject to extreme urban conditions.{{citation needed|date=October 2011}}

'''''Quercus myrtifolia''''' ('''myrtle oak''')<ref>{{PLANTS|id=QUMY|taxon=Quercus myrtifolia|accessdate=15 September 2015}}</ref> is a North American species of [[oak]]s in the [[Fagaceae|beech family]]. It is native to the southeastern United States ([[Mississippi]], [[Alabama]], [[Florida]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], [[South Carolina]]). It is often found in coastal areas on sandy soils. <ref name="bonap">{{cite web|url=http://bonap.net/MapGallery/County/Quercus%20myrtifolia.png |title=Biota of North America Program 2014 county distribution map |publisher=bonap.net|accessdate=2015-08-28}}</ref>

''Quercus myrtifolia'' is an evergreen tree that can reach 12 meters (40 feet) tall or shrub in drier sites. It has leaves with no teeth or lobes, hairless on the upperside and also on the underside except along the veins.<ref name="efloras">{{cite web|url=http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=1&taxon_id=233501066 |title=Flora of North America, ''Quercus myrtifolia'' Willdenow, 1805. Myrtle oak |publisher=efloras.org|accessdate=2015-08-28}}</ref>

'''''Quercus nigra''''', the '''water oak''', is an [[oak]] in the [[List of Quercus species#Section Lobatae|red oak]] group (''Quercus'' sect. ''Lobatae''), native to the eastern and south-central [[United States]], found in all the coastal states from [[New Jersey]] to [[Texas]], and inland as far as [[Oklahoma]], [[Kentucky]], and southern [[Missouri]].<ref>[http://bonap.net/MapGallery/County/Quercus%20nigra.png Biota of North America Program 2014 county distribution map]</ref> It occurs in lowlands and up to 450 m (1500 ft) altitude.

==Description==
''Quercus nigra'' is a medium-sized [[deciduous]] [[tree]], growing to 30 m (100 ft)  tall with a trunk up to 1 m (3 ft) in diameter. Young trees have a smooth, brown bark that becomes gray-black with rough scaly ridges as the tree matures. The [[leaf|leaves]] are alternate, simple and tardily deciduous, remaining on the tree until mid-winter; they are 3–12 cm (1–5 in) long and 2–6 cm (1/2–2 in) broad, variable in shape, most commonly shaped like a spatula being broad and rounded at the top and narrow and wedged at the base. The margins vary, usually being smooth to shallowly lobed, with a bristle at the apex and lobe tips. The tree is easy to identify by the leaves, which have a lobe that looks as if a drop of water is hanging from the end of the leaf. The top of each leaf is a dull green to bluish green and the bottom is a paler bluish-green. On the bottom portion of the leaves, rusty colored hairs run along the veins. The [[acorn]]s are arranged singly or in pairs, 10–14 mm (1/3-1/2 in) long and broad, with a shallow cupule; they mature about 18 months after pollination in [[autumn|fall]] of second year.<ref>[http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=1&taxon_id=233501067 Flora of North America: ''Quercus nigra'']</ref>

==Ecology==
[[Image:Quercus nigra.jpg|thumb|left|Water oak leaf cluster]]
Water oak serves the same ecological role as [[Salix babylonica#Horticultural selections and related hybrids|weeping willow]] and other wetland trees. It is adapted to wet, [[swamp]]y areas, such as along [[pond]]s and stream banks, but can also tolerate well-drained sites and even heavy, compacted soils. It grows in sandy soils, red clays, and old fields to the borders of [[swamp]]s, [[stream]]s, to [[bottomland]]s. Due to its ability to grow and reproduce quickly, the water oak is often the most abundant species in a stand of trees. The tree is relatively short-lived compared to other oaks and may live only 60 to 80 years. It does not compete well and does not tolerate even light shade. Water oak is frequently used to restore bottomland [[hardwood forest]]s on land that was previously cleared for agriculture or pine plantations. Minimum age for flowering and fruiting is 20 years and the tree produces heavy crops of acorns nearly every year. Water oak is not recommended as an ornamental due to being short-lived, disease-prone, and extremely messy.

[[Hybrid (biology)|Hybrids]] of water oak are known with southern red oak (''[[Quercus falcata]]''), bluejack oak (''[[Quercus incana]]''), turkey oak (''[[Quercus laevis]]''), blackjack oak (''[[Quercus marilandica]]''), willow oak (''[[Quercus phellos]]''), Shumard oak (''[[Quercus shumardii]]''), and black oak (''[[Quercus velutina]]'')

Water oak acorns are an important food for [[white-tailed deer]], [[eastern gray squirrel]], [[raccoon]], [[wild turkey]], [[mallard]], [[wood duck]], and [[bobwhite quail]]. In winter, deer will browse the buds and young twigs.

==Uses and history==
Water oak has been used for timber and for [[firewood|fuel]] by people in the southern states since the 17th century. The wood is generally sold as "red oak", mixed with the wood from other red oaks.

Other names include spotted oak, duck oak, punk oak, orange oak or possum oak.

'''''Quercus oglethorpensis''''' (also called '''Oglethorpe oak''') is a species of [[plant]] in the [[Fagaceae|beech family]]. It is [[Endemism|endemic]] to the [[United States]].  It is named for [[Oglethorpe County, Georgia]], where it was first discovered.<ref name="B&K" /> The county, in turn, is named for [[James Oglethorpe]], founder of [[Georgia Colony]] in the 18th Century.<ref>[http://www.georgiaencyclopedia.org/articles/history-archaeology/james-oglethorpe-1696-1785 New Georgia Encyclopedia]</ref>

==Description==
''Quercus oglethorpensis'' is a tree growing to approximately 25 meters (83 feet) in height, with a [[diameter at breast height]] of about 80 cm (32 inches. Bark is white or pale gray. Leaves are narrowly elliptical, up to 15 cm (6 inches) long, usually flat rather than cupped, usually with no lobes. <ref name="Duncan" /><ref>[http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=1&taxon_id=233501069 Flora of North America, ''Quercus oglethorpensis'' Duncan, 1940.  Oglethorpe oak ]</ref>

==Distribution==
''Quercus oglethorpensis'' is found in the [[Piedmont (United States)|Piedmont]] of [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] and [[South Carolina]], and in [[Alabama]], [[Louisiana]] and [[Mississippi]].<ref>[http://bonap.net/MapGallery/County/Quercus%20oglethorpensis.png Biota of North America Program 2014 county distribution map]</ref><ref name="B&K">{{Cite book|last=Brown|first=Claud L.|author2=L. Katherine Kirkman |title=Trees of Georgia and Adjacent States|publisher=[[Timber Press]]|location=[[Portland, Oregon]]|date=1990|pages=110|isbn=0-88192-148-3}}</ref><ref name="Duncan">{{Cite book|last=Duncan|first=Wilbur H.|author2=Marion B. Duncan |title=Trees of the Southeastern United States|publisher=[[University of Georgia Press]]|location=[[Athens, Georgia]]|date=1988|pages=250|isbn=0-8203-1469-2}}</ref><ref>Nixon, K. ''et al.'' 1998.  [http://www.iucnredlist.org/search/details.php/30956/all ''Quercus oglethorpensis''] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140627000000/http://www.iucnredlist.org/search/details.php/30956/all |date=27 June 2014 }}.   [http://www.iucnredlist.org 2006 IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140627000000/http://www.iucnredlist.org |date=27 June 2014 }}  Downloaded on 23 August 2007.</ref>

==Diseases==
This species is commonly affected by [[chestnut blight]].<ref name="B&K" /><ref name="Duncan" />

176.text:
{{for|the town in Florida|Willow Oak, Florida}}
{{italic title}}
{{taxobox
|name = Willow oak
|image = WillowOakinAutumn.JPG
|image_caption = Quercus phellos in autumn foliage
|regnum = [[Plant]]ae
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]]
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]]
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosids]]
|ordo = [[Fagales]]
|familia = [[Fagaceae]]
|genus = ''[[oak|Quercus]]''
|sectio = ''[[List of Quercus species#Section Lobatae|Lobatae]]''
|species = '''''Q. phellos'''''
|binomial = ''Quercus phellos''
|binomial_authority = [[Carl Linnaeus|L.]] 1753 not Münchh. 1770
|range_map = Quercus phellos range map 1.png
}}

'''''Quercus phellos''''' ('''willow oak''') is a North American species of a [[deciduous]] [[tree]] in the [[List of Quercus species#Section Lobatae|red oak]] group of [[oak]]s. It is native to the eastern and central United States from [[Long Island Sound]] (NY and CT) south to northern [[Florida]], and west to southernmost [[Illinois]], [[Missouri]], [[Oklahoma]], and eastern [[Texas]].<ref>{{BONAP|ref|genus=Quercus|species=phellos}}</ref> It is most commonly found growing on lowland [[floodplain]]s, often along [[stream]]s, but rarely also in uplands with poor drainage, up to {{convert|400|m|ft|sp=us}} altitude.

==Description==
It is a medium-sized tree growing to {{convert|20|–|30|m|ft|round=5}} tall (exceptionally to {{convert|39|m|ft|disp=comma|abbr=on}}), with a trunk up to {{convert|1|–|1.5|m|in|round=5|abbr=on}} diameter (exceptionally {{convert|2|m|ft|disp=comma}}). It is distinguished from most other oaks by its [[leaf|leaves]], which are shaped like [[willow]] leaves, {{convert|5|–|12|cm|in|frac=4|abbr=on}} long and {{convert|1|–|2.5|cm|in|frac=8|abbr=on}} broad with an entire (untoothed and unlobed) margin; they are bright green above, paler beneath, usually hairless but sometimes downy beneath. The [[fruit]] is an [[acorn]], {{convert|8|–|12|mm|in|frac=32|abbr=on}} long, and almost as wide as long, with a shallow cup; it is one of the most prolific producers of acorns, an important food tree for [[squirrel]]s, [[bird]]s, and other animals in the forest. The tree starts acorn production around 15 years of age, earlier than many oak species.<ref>{{eFloras|1|233501073|Quercus phellos}}</ref>

[[File:2014-11-02 12 55 20 Willow Oak foliage during autumn along Great Woods Drive in Ewing, New Jersey.JPG|thumb|left|Autumn foliage]]
Willow oaks can grow moderately fast (height growth up to {{convert|60|cm|ft|0|abbr=on|disp=comma}} a year), and tend to be conic to oblong when young, rounding out and gaining girth at maturity (i.e. more than 50 years).

==Cultivation and uses==

Economic uses are primarily as an [[ornamental tree]] and the [[wood]] for [[wood pulp|pulp]] and [[paper]] production, but also for lumber; it is often marketed as "red oak" wood.

The willow oak is one of the most popular trees for [[horticulture|horticultural]] planting, due to its rapid growth, hardiness, balance between axial and radial dominance, ability to withstand both sun and shade, light green leaf color and full crown. Despite being massively planted in the U.S. South (such as [[Washington, D.C.]], and [[Atlanta, Georgia]]) around malls, along roads, etc., the trees tend to grow larger than planners expect, which often leads to cracked sidewalks. One intriguing solution being tried in D.C. is to use 'rubber' sidewalks, made from recycled tires.<ref>[http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/14030187  Rubber sidewalks take the sting out of falls.  Small Business on NBC News]</ref>

'''''Quercus prinoides''''', commonly known as '''dwarf chinkapin oak''', '''dwarf chinquapin oak''', '''dwarf chestnut oak''' or '''scrub chestnut oak''', is a shrubby, [[cloning|clone-forming]] [[Quercus|oak]] native to eastern and central [[North America]], ranging from [[New Hampshire]] to the [[Carolinian forest]] zone of [[southern Ontario]] to eastern [[Nebraska]], south to [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], [[Alabama]], [[Louisiana]], and [[Oklahoma]]. It has a virtually [[Disjunct distribution|disjunct]] (discontinuous) distribution, fairly common in [[New England]] and in the [[Appalachian Mountains]], and also in the eastern [[Great Plains]] but rare in the [[Ohio Valley]] in between.<ref>[http://bonap.net/MapGallery/County/Quercus%20prinoides.png Biota of North America Program 2014 county distribution map]</ref>

==Classification and nomenclature==
''Quercus prinoides'' was named and described by the German botanist [[Carl Ludwig Willdenow|Karl (Carl) Ludwig Willdenow]] in 1801,<ref Name="FNA Qprinoides">{{cite web|title=Quercus prinoides|url=http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=1&taxon_id=233501075|work=Flora of North America|accessdate=8 October 2011}}</ref> in a German journal article by the German-American Pennsylvania botanist [[Gotthilf Heinrich Ernst Muhlenberg]].<ref>Muhlenberg, Gotthilf Heinrich Ernest. 1801.  Der Gesellsschaft Naturforschender Freunde zu Berlin, neue Schriften 3: 397</ref> The epithet ''prinoides'' refers to its resemblance to [[Quercus prinus|''Quercus prinus'', the chestnut oak]].

However, this shrubby oak, now generally accepted as a distinct species, is more closely related to [[Quercus muehlenbergii|chinkapin oak (''Quercus muhlenbergii'')]] than to chestnut oak.<ref Name="FNA Qprinoides" />  These two kinds of oak have sometimes been considered to be [[conspecific]] (belonging to the same species), in which case the earlier-published name ''Q. prinoides'' has priority, with the larger chinkapin oak then usually classified as ''Quercus prinoides'' var. ''acuminata'', and the shrubby form as ''Q. prinoides'' var. ''prinoides''.

== Description ==

The dwarf chinkapin oak is a shrub or small tree that typically only grows to 13–20 feet (4–6 meters) tall and 13–20 feet (4–6 meters) wide. It sometimes spreads vegetatively by means of underground rhizomes.<ref>Hightshoe, G.L. (1988). Native Trees, Shrubs, and Vines for Urban and Rural America. New York: Van Nostrand Reinhold.</ref> The leaves of dwarf chinkapin oak closely resemble those of chinkapin oak, although they are smaller: 2-6 inches (5–15 cm) long, compared to 4-7 inches (10–18 cm) long for chinkapin oak.  The acorns are 1/2 to 1 inches (15–25 mm) long, with the cup enclosing about half of the acorn.<ref Name="FNA Qprinoides" />

While similar in foliage and fruits, but with smaller leaves, the dwarf chinkapin oak may also be distinguished from the chinkapin oak by differences in growth habit (the clonally spreading shrubby growth form and smaller proportions of dwarf chinkapin oak, even when grown on rich soils) and habitat (the chinkapin oak is typically found on rocky, [[calcareous]] sites, while the dwarf chinkapin oak is more typically found on dry, often [[soil pH|acidic]], sandy soils or dry shales).<ref Name="FNA Qprinoides" />

==Ecology and uses==
[[File:NAS-011f Quercus prinoides acorn.png|thumb|A dwarf chinkapin oak acorn, detail from an engraving after [[Pancrace Bessa]], ca. 1812.]]
{{expand section|date=October 2011}}
The acorns of dwarf chinkapin oak are sweet tasting and relished by humans and many kinds of wildlife.  The wood has little commercial value because of the shrub's small size.

==References==
{{reflist}}

==External links==
* Sternberg, G. 1998.  [http://www.iucnredlist.org/search/details.php/33897/all ''Quercus prinoides''].   [https://web.archive.org/web/20140627094911/http://www.iucnredlist.org/ 2006 IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. ]  Downloaded on 23 August 2007.

'''''Quercus rubra''''', commonly called '''northern red oak''', or '''champion oak''', ([[synonymy|syn.]] ''Quercus borealis''), is an [[oak]] in the [[List of Quercus species#Section Lobatae|red oak]] group (''Quercus'' section ''Lobatae''). It is a native of North America, in the eastern and central United States and southeast and south-central Canada. It grows from the north end of the [[Great Lakes (North America)|Great Lakes]], east to [[Nova Scotia]], south as far as [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], [[Alabama]], and [[Louisiana]], and west to [[Oklahoma]], [[Kansas]], [[Nebraska]], and [[Minnesota]].<ref>{{BONAP|ref|genus=Quercus|species=rubra}}</ref> It has been introduced to small areas in Western Europe, where it can frequently be seen cultivated in gardens and parks. It prefers good soil that is slightly [[Soil pH|acidic]]. Often simply called '''red oak''', northern red oak is so named to distinguish it from [[southern red oak]] (''[[Quercus falcata|Q. falcata]]''), also known as the Spanish oak. It is also the [[List of U.S. state trees|state tree]] of [[New Jersey]] and the [[list of Canadian provincial and territorial symbols|provincial tree]] of [[Prince Edward Island]].

== Description ==
[[File:Quercusrubra.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Wood of the Red Oak. From [[Romeyn Beck Hough]]'s fourteen-volume work ''The American Woods'', a collection of over 1000 paper-thin wood samples representing more than 350 varieties of North American tree.]]
In many forests, this deciduous tree grows straight and tall, to {{convert|28|m|ft|abbr=on}}, exceptionally to {{convert|43|m|ft|abbr=on}} tall, with a trunk of up to {{convert|50|–|100|cm|in|abbr=on}} diameter. Open-grown trees do not get as tall, but can develop a stouter trunk, up to {{convert|2|m|ft|abbr=on}} in diameter. It has stout branches growing at right angles to the stem, forming a narrow round-topped head. It grows rapidly and is tolerant of many soils and varied situations, although it prefers the glacial drift and well-drained borders of streams.<ref name=Keeler>{{cite book
  | last =Keeler
  | first =Harriet L.
  | title =Our Native Trees and How to Identify Them
  | publisher =Charles Scriber's Sons
  | year =1900
  | location =New Roak
  | pages =349–354 }}</ref> It is frequently a part of the canopy in an [[oak-heath forest]], but generally not as important as some other oaks.<ref>[http://www.dcr.virginia.gov/natural_heritage/ncTIIIe.shtml ''The Natural Communities of Virginia Classification of Ecological Community Groups'' (Version 2.3), Virginia Department of Conservation and Recreation, 2010] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110105224138/http://www.dcr.virginia.gov/natural_heritage/ncTIIIe.shtml |date=January 5, 2011 }}</ref><ref>Schafale, M. P. and A. S. Weakley. 1990. ''Classification of the natural communities of North Carolina: third approximation''. North Carolina Natural Heritage Program, North Carolina Division of Parks and Recreation.</ref><ref name=tammy />

Under optimal conditions and full sun, northern red oak is fast growing and a 10-year-old tree can be {{convert|5|–|6|m|ft|abbr=on}} tall.<ref name=www.arborday.org>[http://www.arborday.org/trees/treeGuide/TreeDetail.cfm?id=20 Arbor Day Foundation, Northern Red Oak]</ref> Trees may live up to 500 years according to the [[USDA]],<ref name=plants.usda.gov>[http://plants.usda.gov/plantguide/pdf/cs_quru.pdf United States Department of Agriculture Plant Guide]</ref> and a living example of 326 years was noted in 2001 by Orwig et al.<ref name=tammy /><ref name="people.eku.edu/pedersonn/OLDLISTeast">[http://people.eku.edu/pedersonn/OLDLISTeast Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory and Columbia University, Eastern US oldlist]</ref>

Northern red oak is easy to recognize by its bark, which feature bark ridges that appear to have shiny stripes down the center. A few other oaks have bark with this kind of appearance in the upper tree, but the northern red oak is the only tree with the striping all the way down the trunk.<ref name=tammy />

* Bark: Dark reddish grey brown, with broad, thin, rounded ridges, scaly. On young trees and large stems, smooth and light gray. Rich in tannic acid. Branchlets slender, at first bright green, shining, then dark red, finally dark brown. Bark is brownish gray, becoming dark brown on old trees.
* Wood: Pale reddish brown, sapwood darker, heavy, hard, strong, coarse-grained. Cracks in drying, but when carefully treated could be successfully used for furniture. Also used in construction and for interior finish of houses. Sp. gr., 0.6621; weight of cu. ft., 41.25 lbs.
* Winter buds: Dark chestnut brown (reddish brown), ovate, acute, generally 6 mm long<ref name=tammy />
* Leaves: Alternate, seven to nine-lobed, oblong-ovate to oblong, five to ten inches long, four to six inches broad; seven to eleven lobes tapering gradually from broad bases, acute, and usually repandly dentate and terminating with long bristle-pointed teeth; the second pair of lobes from apex are largest; midrib and primary veins conspicuous. Lobes are less deeply cut than most other oaks of the red oak group (except for [[Quercus velutina|black oak]] which can be similar). Leaves emerge from the bud convolute, pink, covered with soft silky down above, coated with thick white tomentum below. When full grown are dark green and smooth, sometimes shining above, yellow green, smooth or hairy on the axils of the veins below. In autumn they turn a rich red, sometimes brown. Often the petiole and midvein are a rich red color in midsummer and early autumn, though this is not true of all red oaks. The acorns mature in about 18 months after [[pollination]]; solitary or in pairs, sessile or stalked; nut oblong-ovoid with broad flat base, full, with acute apex, one half to one and one-fourth of an inch long, first green, maturing nut-brown; cup, saucer-shaped and shallow, {{convert|2|cm|in|abbr=on}} wide, usually covering only the base, sometimes one-fourth of the nut, thick, shallow, reddish brown, somewhat downy within, covered with thin imbricated reddish brown scales. Its kernel is white and very bitter.<ref name=Keeler />  Despite this bitterness, they are eaten by [[deer]], [[squirrels]] and [[birds]].<ref name=tammy />

Red oak acorns, unlike the white oak group, display epigeal dormancy and will not germinate without a minimum of three months' exposure to sub-{{convert|40|°F|°C|abbr=on}} temperatures. They also take two years of growing on the tree before development is completed.<ref name=tammy>[http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=1&taxon_id=233501079 Flora of North America: ''Quercus rubra'']</ref>

{{Gallery
|File:2013-05-12 13 17 43 Immature Red Oak foliage along the Wanaque Ridge Trail in Ramapo Mountain State Forest, New Jersey.jpg|Immature foliage in Ramapo Mountain State Forest, New Jersey
|File:2014-10-30 10 49 37 Red Oak foliage during autumn on Farrell Avenue in Ewing, New Jersey.JPG|Autumn foliage
|File:Autumn Red Oak Leaf.jpg|Autumn red oak leaf
|File:Red Oak Quercus Rubra Bark Vertical High DoF.JPG|Detail of mature bark
|File:Quercus_rubra_IP0905004.jpg|Red oak sapling in Hohenlohe, Germany
|File:Quercus rubra Blüte.jpg
}}

== Uses ==
[[File:Red Oak (2046975257).jpg|thumb|right|Red oak in [[Appalachian Mountains|Appalachian]] mountains]]
The northern red oak is one of the most important oaks for [[timber]] production in North America. Quality red oak is of high value as lumber and veneer, while defective logs are used as [[firewood]]. Other related oaks are also cut and marketed as red oak, although their wood is not always of as high a quality. These include [[eastern black oak]], [[scarlet oak]], [[pin oak]], [[Shumard oak]], [[southern red oak]] and other species in the red oak group. Construction uses include flooring, veneer, interior trim, and furniture. It is also used for lumber, railroad ties, and fence posts.

Red oak wood grain is so open that smoke can be blown through it from end-grain to end-grain on a flat-sawn board. For this reason, it is subject to moisture infiltration and is unsuitable for outdoor uses such as boatbuilding or exterior trim.{{Citation needed|date=December 2014}}

=== Ornamental use ===
''Quercus rubra'' is grown in parks and large gardens as a specimen tree.<ref>{{cite web|title=RHS Plant Selector – ''Quercus rubra''|url=http://apps.rhs.org.uk/plantselector/plant?plantid=3485|accessdate=27 June 2013}}</ref> It is not planted as often as the closely related [[Pin Oak]] as it develops a taproot and quickly becomes difficult to transplant. Acorns should either be sown in the location where the tree is intended to be planted or else moved to their permanent location within the seedling's first year. As the tree gets older, the taproot gradually becomes less dominant and the lateral root network expands. Northern Red Oak is easy to start from seed, however the acorns must be protected from animal predation over the winter months.

As with other oaks, germination takes place in late spring when all frost danger has passed. The seedling grows rapidly for its first month, then pauses for another month, and sends out more new shoots until September when growth stops for the year. If the weather stays favorable, a third burst of growth may occur.

This oak is grown across Canada almost everywhere it will grow. It has naturalized in southeastern British Columbia near the Alberta border.

== Famous specimens ==
*[[Ashford Oak]] – A very large Northern Red Oak in [[Ashford, Connecticut|Ashford]], Connecticut. The tree has suffered falling limbs because of its great age. However, this tree is still a sight to behold; the trunk is {{convert|8|m|ft|abbr=on}} in circumference and the root-knees are also particularly impressive. The oak is located on Giant Oak Lane off [[U.S. Highway 44]]. There are several other large oaks in the area.<ref name="Great Trees">{{Citation
  | last =Rucker
  | first =Colby B.
  | author-link =
  | last2 =
  | first2 =
  | author2-link =
  | title =Great Eastern Trees, Past and Present
  | date =February 2004
  | url =http://www.nativetreesociety.org/bigtree/great_eastern_trees.htm
  | accessdate = 2007-05-05 }}</ref>

*[[Chase Creek Red Oak]] – This forest tree is located on a very rich steep slope in [[Anne Arundel County]], [[Maryland]]. It is a high-stump [[coppice]] with three leads. It was the state champion oak in Maryland in 2002. The circumference at breast height is {{convert|6.7|m|ft|abbr=on}}, the height {{convert|41.5|m|ft|abbr=on}} and the spread {{convert|29.9|m|ft|abbr=on}}<ref name="Great Trees" />
*[[Shera-Blair Red Oak]] – This majestic red oak tree is located on Shelby Street in the South Frankfort neighborhood in  [[Franklin County, Kentucky|Franklin County]], [[Kentucky]], and is the largest red oak tree in the oldest neighborhood in [[Frankfort, Kentucky|Frankfort]], [[Kentucky]]. It is in the backyard of a house built in 1914 by architect Arthur Raymond Smith, who at one time worked for D.X. Murphy & Bros., famed architects that designed the twin spires at [[Churchill Downs]]. The circumference at breast height is {{convert|6.4|m|ft|abbr=on}}, with the trunk reaching higher than 40 feet before the branches begin and an estimated height of 130 feet.

'''''Quercus sinuata''''', the '''bastard oak''',<ref>{{PLANTS|id=QUSI|taxon=Quercus sinuata|accessdate=15 September 2015}}</ref> '''bastard white oak''',<ref name="fna"/> or '''Durand oak''',<ref name="fna"/> is a North American species of [[oak]]. It is native to northern Mexico ([[Coahuila]], [[Nuevo León]], and [[Tamaulipas]]) as well as  to the southeastern and south-central United States (from [[Texas]] and [[Oklahoma]] to the [[Carolinas]]).<ref name="fna">[http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=1&taxon_id=233501084 ''Quercus sinuata'' in Flora of North America]</ref><ref>[http://bonap.net/MapGallery/County/Quercus%20sinuata.png Biota of North America Program 2014 county distribution map]</ref>

''Quercus sinuata'' is a deciduous tree up to 20 meters (67 feet) tall. Leaves are narrow, with shallow rounded lobes. It tends to grow in wet habitats, such as on river bluffs, river bottoms, and flatwoods, and generally over basic substrates, such as mafic rocks, shells, or calcareous sediment.<ref name="fna" /><ref name="weakley">[http://www.herbarium.unc.edu/flora.htm Flora of the Southern and Mid-Atlantic States by Alan S. Weakley]</ref>

;Varieties<ref name=tabby/><ref name="fna" />
*''Quercus sinuata'' var. ''breviloba'' <small>(Torr.) C.H.Mull.</small> - Texas, Oklahoma, Mexico
*''Quercus sinuata'' var. ''sinuata'' - Alabama, [[Arkansas]], [[Florida]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], [[Louisiana]], [[Mississippi]], [[Carolinas]], [[Texas]]

'''''Quercus texana''''', commonly known as '''Nuttall's oak''',<ref name = Kentucky>{{cite web | title = Oaks list for The State Botanical Garden of Kentucky | url = http://www.ca.uky.edu/arboretum/brochures/Oaks.pdf | format = English | accessdate = 2010-05-09}}</ref><ref name = Raulston>{{cite web | title = J.C. Raulston slide 102-0276 | url = http://www.ncsu.edu/jcraulstonarboretum/photography/raulston_slides/raulston_slides_results.php?pageNum_slides_recordset=7&fullsearch=&box=&slide=&date=November%201989&photographer=&country=&usstate=&city=&location=&keywords=&othernotes=&plantnames=&commonnames=&families=&digitized=&plantnameID= | format = English | accessdate = 2010-05-09}}</ref><ref name=Missouri>{{cite web|title=Missouri Department of Conservation Species Scientific Name Index |url=http://mdc.mo.gov/areas/natareas/scientif.htm |format=English |accessdate=2010-05-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090815090721/http://www.mdc.mo.gov/areas/natareas/scientif.htm |archivedate=August 15, 2009 }}</ref><ref name = Illinois>{{cite web | title = University of Illinois Extension; Critical Issues Forum, ''What is the Current Status of Oaks in Illinois?'' | url = http://web.extension.illinois.edu/forestry/critical_issues/diversity_issue.html | format = English | accessdate = 2010-05-09}}</ref> is a fast-growing, large [[deciduous]] [[oak]] [[tree]].

''Quercus texana'' is native to the south-central United States primarily in the lower [[Mississippi River]] Valley in [[Louisiana]], [[Arkansas]], [[Mississippi]], [[Alabama]], and western [[Tennessee]].  There are additional populations in eastern [[Texas]], southeastern [[Oklahoma]], southeastern [[Missouri]], far western [[Kentucky]], and the southernmost tip of [[Illinois]].<ref>[http://bonap.net/MapGallery/County/Quercus%20texana.png Biota of North America Program 2014 county distribution map]</ref>

''Quercus texana'' is a tree up to 25 meters (83 feet) tall, with dark brown bark.  It has leaves with sharp pointed lobes somewhat similar to those of the Georgia oak (''[[Quercus georgiana]]'') and pin oak (''[[Quercus palustris]]'').<ref>[http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=1&taxon_id=233501089 Flora of North America, ''Quercus texana'' Buckley, 1860.  Texas red oak, Nuttall's oak ]</ref> It is fast-growing and usually has nice red fall colors, much more reliably so than the more popular pin oak. It is still relatively obscure in the horticultural industry but is slowly gaining popularity due to its fast growth rate, ease of transplanting, good fall colors and ability to grow in wet soils.

This species was for years erroneously called ''Quercus nuttallii'', but it is now known as ''Quercus texana''; this has created much confusion with Texas red oak which was known as ''Quercus texana'' but is now known as ''[[Quercus buckleyi]]''.<ref>[http://www.jstor.org/pss/1221780  Laurence J. Dorr and Kevin C. Nixon. 1985. Typification of the Oak (''Quercus'') Taxa Described by S. B. Buckley (1809-1884). Taxon 34(2): 211-228.]</ref>

{{Italic title}}{{taxobox
|name = ''Rhizophora mangle''
|image = Rhizophora mangle00.jpg
|image_caption = <center>1796 Plate by [[Johannes Zorn]]
|regnum = [[Plant]]ae
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]]
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]]
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosids]]
|ordo = [[Malpighiales]]
|familia = [[Rhizophoraceae]]
|genus = ''[[Rhizophora]]''
|species = '''''R. mangle'''''
|binomial = ''Rhizophora mangle''
|binomial_authority = [[Carl Linnaeus|L.]]
}}
[[File:Rhizophora mangle MHNT.BOT.2010.12.12.jpg|thumb|''Rhizophora mangle'' - [[MHNT]]]]

'''''Rhizophora mangle''''', known as the '''red mangrove''', is distributed in [[Estuary|estuarine]] ecosystems throughout the tropics. Its [[Vivipary|viviparous]] "seeds," in actuality called [[propagule]]s, become fully mature plants before dropping off the parent tree. These are dispersed by water until eventually embedding in the shallows.

''Rhizophora mangle'' grows on [[Aerial root#Aerial roots as supports|aerial prop roots]], which arch above the water level, giving stands of this tree the characteristic "[[mangrove]]" appearance. It is a valuable plant in Florida, Louisiana, and Texas coastal ecosystems.  In its native habitat it is threatened by invasive species such as the [[Brazilian Pepper|Brazilian pepper tree ''(Schinus terebinthifolius)'']].  The red mangrove itself is considered an [[invasive species]] in some locations, such as [[Hawaii]], where it forms dense, [[monospecific]] thickets.<ref>Allen, J.A., 1998. Mangroves as Alien Species: The Case of Hawaii. ''Global Ecology and Biogeographical Letters'' 7:61-71</ref> ''R. mangle'' thickets, however, provide nesting and hunting habitat for a diverse array of organisms, including [[fish]], [[bird]]s, and [[crocodile]]s.

==Habitat==
Red mangroves are found in [[subtropical]] and [[tropical]] areas in both [[Earth|hemispheres]], extending to approximately 28°N to S latitude. They thrive on coastlines in [[brackish]] water and in swampy salt marshes. Because they are well adapted to salt water, they thrive where many other plants fail and create their own ecosystems, the [[mangrove|mangal]]s. Red mangroves are often found near white mangroves (''[[Laguncularia racemosa]]''), black mangroves (''[[Avicennia germinans]]''), and buttonwood (''[[Conocarpus erectus]]''). Through stabilisation of their surroundings, mangroves create a community for other plants and animals (such as the [[mangrove crab]]). Though rooted in soil, mangrove roots are often submerged in water for several hours or on a permanent basis. The roots are usually sunk in a [[sand]] or [[clay]] base, which allows for some protection from the waves.

==Description==
Red mangroves are easily distinguishable through their unique prop roots system and [[Vivipary|viviparous]] [[seed]]s. The prop roots of a red mangrove suspend it over the water, thereby giving it extra support and protection. They also help the tree to combat [[Hypoxia (environmental)|hypoxia]] by allowing it a direct intake of oxygen through its [[root]] structure. 

A mangrove can reach up to {{convert|80|ft|m}} in height in ideal conditions; however, it is commonly found at a more modest {{convert|20|ft|m}}. Its bark is thick and a grey-brown color. Mangrove leaves are {{convert|1|-|2|in|cm}} wide and {{convert|3|-|5|in|cm}} long, with smooth margins and an [[elliptical|ellipse]] shape. They are a darker shade of [[green]] on the tops than on the bottoms. The tree produces pale pink [[flower]]s in the spring.

==Reproduction==
As a viviparous plant, ''R. mangle'' creates a propagule that is in reality a living tree. Though resembling an elongated seed pod, the fully-grown propagule on the mangrove is capable of rooting and producing a new tree. The trees are [[Plant sexuality|hermaphrodite]]s, capable of [[Self-pollination|self pollination]] or [[Anemophily|wind pollination]]. The tree undergoes no dormant stage as a seed, but rather progresses to a live plant before leaving its parent tree. A mangrove propagule may float in brackish water for over a year before rooting.

==Common names==
As well as the English name "red mangrove," ''R. mangle'' is known in [[Tonga]] as ''tongo''.<ref>{{cite web|title=Rhizophora|url=http://eol.org/pages/60810/details|work=Encyclopedia of Life|accessdate=28 November 2012}}</ref>

==Gallery==

Image:Plody mangrovnika (Rhizophora mangle).jpg|Propagules growing before dropping from the parent plant. (BioBay, [[Vieques]])
Image:Red mangrove forest, Fajardo, Puerto Rico.jpg|A red mangrove forest in [[Fajardo]], [[Puerto Rico]]
Image:Mangroves.jpg|Root structure above and below water.
File:2017 Sarasota Red Mangrove Tunnels 2 FRD 9456.jpg|An [[ecotourist]] on a kayak tunnels through red mangrove trees and roots at [[Lido Key]]
</gallery>
